Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Mentoring Consortium at the Twelfth International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the travel of US doctoral students to, and their participation in the Twelfth International Joint Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems (AAMAS 2013), and the doctoral consortium to be held in conjunction with it.

AAMAS is the premier international conference devoted to all aspects of agent technology and its applications in the World Wide Web, electronic commerce, digital libraries, search, personalization, etc. The Doctoral Consortium offers the students an opportunity to present their research and receive in-depth feedback from senior researchers. Students will benefit from attending the conference, with its rich technical program of contributed and invited research talks, complemented by focused workshops, tutorials and other events.

The student travel awards will help enrich the eduation and training of a diverse group of young researchers, including women and members of underrepresented groups, working in Artificial Intelligence in general, and Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems in particular.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is  to support the participation of a select group of graduate students from US institutions in the Twelfth  International Joint Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS 2013) and the doctoral mentoring consortium (DMC) associated with it in  Saint Paul, Minnesota, May 6-10, 2013. The goal of the DMC offers students an opportunity to present their research and receive in-depth feedback from senior researchers and peers. It also provides pariticapnts with the opportunity to receive advice on managing their careers. The DMC is typically scheduled on the first day of the conference so that the participants can meet with their mentors and peers and continue their discussions through out the duration of the conference and beyond.

The major outcomes of this project are the following:  Twenty one students, including several from underrepresented groups in Computing, from U.S. schools across the nation were funded by this grant to participate in the AAMAS 13 DMC held on May 6, 2013, the first day of the conference. The URL is at http://aamas2013.cs.umn.edu/node/35. The DMC included eight technical talks by students selected to present at the DMC, twenty five poster sessions, a keynote address by a senior researcher in multiagent systems, a one-hour career panel led by researchers from academia and industry that included a 45 minute question and answer session and finally a small group discussion with role playing activities led by senior researchers. Students were assigned mentors in their research interest area at the DMC.  The DMC had over 60 participants in all and was a good opportunity for NSF funded participants to learn about being successful researchers in this critically important field from their peers as well senior researchers and to connect to the larger AAMAS community. Several scholarship recipients reported that the opportunities to meet with their assigned mentor and connect with their fellow DMC participants through the rest of the conference especially beneficial in building their research community. The participants presented their research on multiagent systems topics that were relevant to applications ranging from economics, social networks, biological systems, theatre and video. The discussions from the DMC has the potential to impact all of these areas. In summary, the student travel awards provided by this grant provided opportunities to enrich the education and training of a diverse group of young researchers, including those from underrepresented groups, working in Artificial Intelligence in general and Autonomous Agents and Multi-agent Systems in particular.
